To estimation the disease prevalence in total population
To estimate the fatality of the disease

questions.text: Following is part of sentinel surveillance except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) To estimate the fatality of the disease. Sentinel surveillance is a system in which selected health facilities (called sentinel sites) actively monitor specific diseases or health conditions. It is used to track trends, detect outbreaks early, and identify missing cases that might not be captured by routine surveillance. However, it is not designed to estimate disease fatality (case fatality rate, CFR), as sentinel sites focus on case detection rather than outcome measurement. A. Method for identifying the missing cases – Correct. Sentinel surveillance helps detect underreported or missing cases that may not appear in routine reporting systems. This is especially useful for infectious diseases like dengue, influenza, or polio, where not all cases are formally reported. B. Supplementing the notified cases – Correct. Sentinel surveillance enhances existing surveillance systems by providing additional data that may not be captured through routine notifications. It helps verify and strengthen disease reporting. C. To estimate the disease prevalence in total population – Correct. While sentinel surveillance does not provide precise prevalence rates, it can give an estimate of how common a disease is in the broader population by analyzing data from selected sites. These estimates are often used for trends and early warnings.

questions.text: A carrier who gets infected from another carrier is known as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Paradoxical carrier. A paradoxical carrier refers to a situation where an individual becomes infected from another carrier, even though they may have previously been a carrier themselves. This can happen when a carrier becomes infected with a different strain or type of pathogen while still harboring the original infection. Essentially, it is a carrier who becomes infected by another person who is also a carrier of the disease, which is somewhat contradictory or "paradoxical" in nature. Incorrect Options: A. Incubatory carrier: This refers to a person who has been infected with a pathogen and is in the incubation period (the time between infection and onset of symptoms) but is not yet showing symptoms. The individual can still spread the disease to others during this time, but they have not yet been infected by another carrier in the way described in the question. C. Convalescent carrier: This is a person who has recovered from an illness but continues to harbor and spread the pathogen to others. The convalescent carrier is no longer symptomatic but can still transmit the disease. D. Pseudo carrier: This refers to an individual who appears to be a carrier of a pathogen but does not actually harbor the infectious agent. This term is less commonly used in medical contexts.

questions.text: In which of the following carrier has no role in transmission?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Measles. In measles, a carrier does not play a role in transmission. Measles is a highly contagious viral infection, and transmission occurs only from person to person through respiratory droplets. An infected individual is contagious during the symptomatic period, but there are no asymptomatic carriers in measles. Therefore, there is no role for a carrier state in the transmission of the disease. Incorrect Options: A. Cholera: This is incorrect. In cholera, asymptomatic carriers can play a significant role in transmission. Individuals who carry Vibrio cholerae without showing symptoms can still shed the bacteria in their feces, contaminating water or food sources and spreading the disease. C. Diphtheria: This is incorrect. In diphtheria, carriers (especially asymptomatic carriers) can still transmit the bacteria to others, even if they do not show symptoms. The bacteria are typically spread through respiratory droplets or contact with contaminated surfaces. D. Typhoid: This is incorrect. In typhoid fever, asymptomatic carriers (such as the famous "Typhoid Mary") can harbor the Salmonella typhi bacteria and spread it to others, even without showing symptoms. These carriers can be significant contributors to the transmission of the disease.

Correct Answer (C) Both. In both malaria and filariasis, humans are considered secondary hosts. A secondary host is an organism that harbors the parasite during part of its lifecycle but is not the organism in which the parasite reaches sexual maturity. Malaria: In malaria, the primary host is the female Anopheles mosquito, which carries the parasite Plasmodium and transmits it to humans. Humans are the secondary host, where the parasite undergoes asexual reproduction, multiplying in the liver and red blood cells before being transmitted back to the mosquito. Humans serve as a key part of the parasite's lifecycle, but the mosquito is the primary host responsible for the sexual reproduction of the parasite. Filariasis: In filariasis, caused by parasitic worms such as Wuchereria bancrofti, the primary host is also the mosquito, which transmits the larvae to humans through a bite. Humans are the secondary hosts, where the larvae develop into adult worms in the lymphatic system. The microfilariae produced by adult worms are then taken up by mosquitoes, continuing the cycle. Incorrect Options: A. Malaria: This is incomplete. While humans are the secondary hosts in malaria, the question asks for the correct answer in the context of both diseases. Therefore, just saying malaria is not enough, as it doesn’t account for filariasis as well. B. Hydatid disease: This is incorrect. In hydatid disease, humans are not the secondary hosts; they are considered accidental or intermediate hosts. The primary hosts for the parasite (usually Echinococcus species) are carnivores like dogs. Humans can become infected by ingesting eggs from the environment but do not play the same role in the lifecycle as secondary hosts. D. Filariasis only: This is incorrect because, while humans are secondary hosts in filariasis, the question is about both diseases (malaria and filariasis). Therefore, the correct response should involve both conditions.

It is likely to be more for infection that do not have a sub clinical phase

questions.text: All of the following are true about the Herd immunity for infectious disease except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It is likely to be more for infection that do not have a subclinical phase. Herd immunity refers to the protection of a population from an infectious disease when a sufficient proportion of individuals are immune (either through vaccination or prior infection), which helps reduce the overall spread of the disease. However, subclinical phases (where individuals are infected but do not show symptoms) do not necessarily affect the level of herd immunity. Herd immunity depends on how many people are immune, and even infections with a subclinical phase can contribute to the immunity of the population without preventing herd immunity from being effective. Incorrect Options: A. It refers to group protection beyond what is afforded by the protection of immunized individuals: This is correct. Herd immunity occurs when enough individuals in a community are immune to a disease (through vaccination or previous infection), providing indirect protection to those who are not immune. This protection extends beyond the immunized individuals and helps limit the spread of the disease. C. It is affected by the presence and distribution of alternative animal hosts: This is correct. For some diseases, the presence of animal hosts (reservoirs) can affect herd immunity. If an animal host can act as a reservoir for the disease, it can continue to spread the infection to humans, reducing the effectiveness of herd immunity in humans. This is often the case with diseases that have zoonotic transmission. D. In case of tetanus it does not protect the individual: This is correct. Tetanus does not have herd immunity because it is not transmitted from person to person. The disease is caused by Clostridium tetani bacteria entering the body through wounds, and vaccination prevents individual infection, but it does not protect the community in the same way as diseases that are spread person-to-person.

questions.text: Consider the following statements: The term’ disease control’ describes ongoing operations aimed at reducing the 1. Incidence of disease 2. Financial burden to the community 3. Effects of infection including both physical and psychological complications 4. Duration of disease and its transmission of these statements:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1, 2, and 4 are correct. Disease control involves a series of strategies aimed at reducing the incidence of disease (the number of new cases), the financial burden on the community, and the duration of the disease along with its transmission. These elements are essential to control the spread and impact of a disease. Disease control strategies focus on minimizing the occurrence and spread of diseases, as well as the time individuals are affected, thus reducing the overall burden on both individuals and society. 1. Incidence of disease: This is correct. A key goal of disease control is to reduce the number of new cases (incidence) of a disease in a population. This can be achieved through measures such as vaccination, early detection, and preventive interventions. 2. Financial burden to the community: This is correct. Disease control aims to reduce the financial strain on healthcare systems and communities by decreasing the number of people affected by the disease and the resources needed to manage it. The fewer cases there are, the lower the costs for treatment and care. 4. Duration of disease and its transmission: This is correct. Disease control efforts seek to reduce the duration of illness by promoting timely treatment, which limits how long an individual is affected by the disease. Additionally, reducing the transmission of the disease (how it spreads) helps control outbreaks and limits its impact on the broader population. Explanation of Incorrect Statements:. 3. Effects of infection including both physical and psychological complications: This is incorrect in the context of disease control. While addressing the effects of infections is important, it is more related to disease management and treatment, not directly to disease control. Disease control is more focused on preventing new cases and minimizing the spread, rather than treating complications that arise after infection.

questions.text: An epidemic of Hepatitis A is an example of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Propagated epidemic. Hepatitis A typically spreads through person-to-person contact, often due to contaminated food or water, and can spread progressively from one individual to others over time. This makes it a propagated epidemic, where the disease is transmitted from person to person, resulting in a gradual increase in the number of cases. Incorrect Options: A. Common Source, single exposure epidemic: This type of epidemic occurs when a large number of people are exposed to a single source of infection at the same time, such as a contaminated food or water source. While Hepatitis A can sometimes spread through contaminated food or water, the disease generally spreads gradually through person-to-person transmission, not from a single exposure. B. Common Source, continuous exposure epidemic: This occurs when people are continuously exposed to the same source of infection over time, such as in the case of a contaminated water supply. Hepatitis A outbreaks can sometimes involve a contaminated source, but its transmission pattern is typically person-to-person, not sustained exposure from a single source. D. Slow epidemic: A slow epidemic refers to a disease that spreads gradually over a long period of time, often due to an environmental factor. Hepatitis A does not typically spread in such a manner; it is generally considered to spread through contact with infected individuals, fitting the definition of a propagated epidemic.

choices.text: Common single source for short period
Common single source for prolonged period

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis was reported from a town between June and August of a particular year. Of total cases 60% occurred in July, exposure of the community to infection is from
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Multiple source for prolonged period. The key information provided is that the outbreak occurred over a span of three months (June to August), with 60% of cases occurring in July. This suggests that the exposure was not limited to a single point in time but rather occurred over a prolonged period, with different sources of infection potentially contributing to the spread. The spread across multiple months points to multiple sources contributing to the outbreak, rather than a single source, and the extended time frame suggests a prolonged period of exposure. Incorrect Options: A. Common single source for short period: This option would apply if the outbreak was limited to a brief period, such as a single event or exposure (e.g., contaminated food or water consumed in a short period). However, the outbreak lasted for three months, and 60% of the cases occurred in one month (July), indicating exposure was over a longer period, not a short one. B. Common single source for prolonged period: This would suggest that a single source of infection caused the outbreak over an extended period. However, the fact that 60% of the cases occurred in one month (July) does not fit the idea of a single source spread evenly over a long time. The outbreak's progression suggests multiple sources of exposure, not just one source. C. Multiple source for short period: This would suggest that the infection was introduced through multiple sources but within a short time frame. Since the outbreak lasted over three months, this doesn't fit the scenario, as the exposure occurred over a prolonged period, not a brief one.

questions.text: A graph shows an uniform curve with no secondary curves the following statement is correct:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Point source epidemic. A point source epidemic occurs when a group of people are exposed to an infectious agent at a single point in time, often from a single source of infection, such as contaminated food or water. The resulting graph typically shows a sharp rise in cases over a short period followed by a rapid decline, forming a uniform curve with no secondary peaks or curves, as described in the question. Incorrect Options: A. Multiple exposure: This would imply that there are multiple sources or points of exposure over time. In such a case, you would expect multiple peaks or secondary curves on the graph, but the description of the uniform curve with no secondary peaks suggests a single point of exposure, not multiple. C. Sporadic: A sporadic disease occurs infrequently and irregularly in the population, often with isolated cases spread out over time and no clear outbreak pattern. A sporadic outbreak would not typically present a uniform curve without secondary peaks, as this would suggest a more focused or concentrated event. D. Pandemic: A pandemic refers to an epidemic that has spread across multiple countries or continents, affecting a large portion of the population. Pandemic outbreaks often involve complex transmission patterns with waves and spikes, not a simple uniform curve with no secondary peaks.

questions.text: Causative agent is present but there is no transmission is known as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Elimination. Elimination refers to the reduction of the incidence of a disease to zero in a specific geographic area as a result of deliberate efforts, but without the complete eradication of the causative agent. In this scenario, the causative agent may still be present, but transmission has ceased, meaning the disease no longer occurs in that area. Incorrect Options: B. Control: Disease control refers to the reduction in the incidence and prevalence of a disease to acceptable levels within a given population. In control efforts, transmission may still occur, but the disease is kept at manageable levels. Transmission is not halted completely as it is in elimination. C. Eradication: Eradication is the permanent reduction to zero of the worldwide incidence of a disease caused by the specific agent, with no further risk of its occurrence. In eradication, the causative agent is completely removed, not just controlled or eliminated from specific areas. D. Holoendemic: A holoendemic disease is one that is consistently present in a community or region, with the population experiencing continuous exposure to the disease. It is not related to the concept of elimination, as transmission is ongoing in a holoendemic setting.

Correct Answer (C) Sentinel surveillance. Sentinel surveillance involves identifying specific sites, or "sentinel" locations, to collect data on particular diseases. These sites are chosen because they can provide early warnings of outbreaks or identify missing cases. This form of surveillance is useful in detecting trends and uncovering cases that may otherwise go undetected in a broader population. Incorrect Options: A. Active surveillance: Active surveillance involves health workers proactively seeking out cases of disease, often by directly contacting health facilities or individuals. While it helps detect cases, it is more focused on ongoing, direct data collection rather than identifying missed cases. B. Passive surveillance: Passive surveillance relies on healthcare providers or other stakeholders to report cases of disease when they occur. This type of surveillance is generally less likely to identify missed cases compared to sentinel surveillance, where specific, focused locations are targeted. D. Monitoring: Monitoring involves tracking and observing the ongoing status of a disease, program, or intervention. It is more of an oversight tool rather than a method specifically for detecting missed cases.

questions.text: Sentinel surveillance is for all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Effective sanitary surveillance. Sentinel surveillance is a focused approach that involves specific locations, known as sentinel sites, to gather data on particular diseases or health events. It is used to monitor specific health indicators, detect early outbreaks, and provide early warning signals. However, it is not typically used for effective sanitary surveillance, which focuses on broader environmental and sanitation conditions. Incorrect Options: A. Border districts: Sentinel surveillance is often implemented in border districts where diseases may cross borders more easily, and focused monitoring is needed to detect outbreaks early. B. For malaria surveillance: Sentinel surveillance is frequently used in malaria surveillance to track disease trends and identify outbreaks, especially in regions where malaria is endemic. D. Supplementary to routine notification: Sentinel surveillance is supplementary to routine notification, meaning it provides additional, focused data to enhance regular disease reporting and improve overall disease monitoring.

Correct Answer (A) Man. The reservoir for hookworm (caused by species like Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus) is man because humans are the primary host for these parasites. The larvae of hookworms are found in the soil, but they do not act as the reservoir; rather, the adult worms reside in the human intestine, where they reproduce and lay eggs that are then passed in the feces. The larvae hatch from the eggs in the soil, and the cycle continues when the larvae infect a new human host. Incorrect Options: B. Soil: While soil is important in the life cycle of hookworms (because the larvae hatch and develop in the soil), it is not the reservoir. The term "reservoir" refers to the living host that maintains and propagates the infection. In this case, that host is the human. C. Both: Since only humans serve as the reservoir for hookworm, this option is incorrect. Soil plays a role in the environmental stages of the parasite's life cycle, but not as a reservoir. D. None: This option is incorrect because humans are the correct reservoir for hookworm.

questions.text: Management of not immunized diphtheria contacts include all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Daily throat examination. Daily throat examination is not typically part of the management for unimmunized diphtheria contacts. Instead, the focus is on preventive measures, including vaccination and microbiological testing, to control the spread of diphtheria. Incorrect Options: A. Complete dose of toxoid – Correct Immunization with the full dose of diphtheria toxoid is given to all unimmunized contacts of diphtheria cases. This is a key preventive measure to protect individuals from developing diphtheria. C. Daily throat swab culture – Correct Daily throat swab cultures are typically used to identify carriers of the diphtheria bacteria among contacts, as they might not show symptoms but could still spread the infection. Regular throat cultures help monitor the potential spread and carrier state.. D. Weekly throat swabs examination – Correct Weekly throat swabs are also part of managing contacts to ensure early detection of any signs of diphtheria and to monitor the situation in case the disease develops among the contacts.

questions.text: Drug of choice for carrier of typhoid is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ampicillin. Ampicillin is one of the preferred antibiotics for treating chronic carriers of Salmonella Typhi. It is effective in eradicating the bacteria from the gallbladder, where chronic carriage usually occurs. Other commonly used drugs for typhoid carriers include Ciprofloxacin (fluoroquinolones) and Azithromycin (macrolides), depending on antibiotic sensitivity patterns. In cases where medical therapy fails, cholecystectomy (surgical removal of the gallbladder) may be required, especially in patients with gallstones, as the bacteria persist in the bile. Incorrect Options: B: Chloramphenicol – Incorrect. While chloramphenicol was historically used for treating acute typhoid fever, it is not preferred for chronic carriers due to a high relapse rate and the development of resistance. C: Cotrimoxazole – Incorrect. Cotrimoxazole (Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole) has been used in the past, but it is less effective than Ampicillin or Fluoroquinolones in eliminating chronic carriage. D: Clindamycin – Incorrect. Clindamycin is not used for typhoid fever or its carrier state because Salmonella Typhi is not susceptible to it. It is primarily used for anaerobic and Gram-positive bacterial infections.

questions.text: Isolation in patient with salmonellosis is done :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Till 3 stool tests are negative. In cases of salmonellosis (including typhoid fever and non-typhoidal Salmonella infections), isolation is maintained until the patient no longer sheds the bacteria in their feces. This is confirmed by three consecutive negative stool cultures, usually taken at least 24 hours apart after completing antibiotic treatment. This practice helps prevent the spread of Salmonella since chronic carriers can continue to shed the bacteria asymptomatically. Chronic carriers (those excreting Salmonella for more than 1 year) are a major concern, particularly in food handlers, healthcare workers, and those with gallbladder disease. Public health measures require clearance of three negative stool cultures before lifting isolation, especially in high-risk individuals. Incorrect Options: A: Till fever subsides – Incorrect. Fever subsiding does not indicate that Salmonella has been completely eradicated from the body. Many patients may still be shedding bacteria in their stool even after clinical recovery. B: Till Widal becomes negative – Incorrect. The Widal test detects antibodies against Salmonella Typhi, but its results do not correlate with active infection or carrier state. Some individuals may have persistent antibodies even after the infection has cleared. D: For 48 hours of chloramphenicol treatment – Incorrect. Chloramphenicol was historically used for typhoid, but treatment alone does not guarantee clearance of bacteria from stool. Some patients may continue to shed bacteria even after successful antibiotic therapy, requiring further stool culture testing.
